Fig. 1 Under (a, b)N-rich and (c, d)C-rich conditions, the formation energies of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 are plotted as a function of the Fermi level with respect to the valence band maximum (VBM). The plot's numbers represent the defect charge state. The shown charge states are the most energetically favorable for each defect at a given Fermi energy (Figs. S7 and S8). (e) Thirty types of stable charge states in 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. Orange represents a system with better bifunctional OER/ORR catalytic activity (Fig. 2). Fig 2 Fig. 3 The free energies linear relationship (a)ΔG*O VS ΔG*OH, (b)ΔG*OOH VS ΔG*OH in 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. The potential-determining steps of OER and ORR are labeled. The (c) OER and (d) ORR contour maps represent the activity trends of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. The ηOER and ηORR can be expressed as the function of ΔG*OH (x-axis) and ΔG* O − ΔG*OH (y-axis). The red dashed lines indicate the Fermi levels. The evolution of the total energy and temperature per atom within 8ps at 300K for (e) Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , (f) Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 , (g) Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and (h) Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 . Pursuing efficient bifunctional oxygen reduction reaction/ oxygen evolution reaction (OER/ORR) electrocatalysts is crucial for realizing sustainable and renewable clean energy, yet it remains a formidable challenge. In this study, we employ density functional theory and machine learning (ML) predictions to systematically investigate the bifunctional OER/ORR activity of 3d transition metal (TM) atom-doped g-C3N3. Our findings reveal that N-rich and C-poor growth conditions can facilitate 3d TM doping into g-C3N3. The Ni occupation N in 0 (Ni× N@C54N53, including 54 C and 53 N atoms), Ni occupation N in +1 (Ni• N@C54N53) and Ni interstitial sites in +1 charge state (Ni• int@C54N54, including 54 C and 54 N atoms) meet the requirements of bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts, which because they (1) have lower formation energies, and (2) lower overpotentials (smaller than 0.47V), (3) can maintain stability under 300K and (4) their band gaps are decreased, which leads to facilitating electron transfer. ML predictions identify the 3d band center (εd ) and the number of 3d electrons (Ne ) as the most effective descriptors for overpotentials of OER and ORR, respectively. This work can pave the way for understanding the origin of bifunctional OER/ORR activity of 3d-TM doped g-C3N3 and benefit the rational design of novel electrocatalysts for other catalytic reactions by considering the charge states. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 3d transition metals doped g-C3N3 Charge states Bifunctional oxygen reduction/evolution reaction Density functional theory calculations Machine learning Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction As concerns grow regarding energy crises and environmental impacts, there is an increasing need to focus on efficient, renewable, and clean energy sources. The urgency to develop novel technologies for the conversion and storage of renewable energy is evident. Rechargeable metal-air batteries [1] and fuel cells [2], owing to their low cost, environmentally friendly nature, and impressive safety performance, have garnered significant attention. Two critical half-reactions involved in the aforementioned energy storage and conversion devices are the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [3,4]. These reactions are instrumental in determining the performance of the devices. In recent times, ruthenium and iridium oxides have emerged as benchmark electrocatalysts for OER, while platinum-based catalysts dominate in the ORR of fuel cells and metal-air batteries [5,6]. However, a significant challenge lies in the development of bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER/ORR, primarily due to the fact that most individual catalysts are only capable of executing specific reactions [7]. Given this, there is a pressing need to design and develop bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts that are abundant in earth, cost-effective, and high-performing. These catalysts hold the potential to replace the currently used noble metal materials, thereby advancing the field of renewable energy storage and conversion. The recent successful synthesis of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N3) with a CN stoichiometry of 1:1, as reported in experiment [8], has opened up new avenues in the field of electrocatalysis. The unique property of g-C3N3, which provides suitable coordination sites for transition metal (TM) atoms, has been identified as a significant advantage. This has led to concerted efforts to establish g-C3N3 as an exceptional substrate for single TM atoms in various electrocatalytic processes, including nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and OER, as referenced in studies [9,10]. The thermodynamic stability of single 3d-TM atoms doped g-C3N3 (3d-TM@C3N3) has been a subject of interest. Chen et al. [11], through their calculations of neutral defect formation energy, have provided evidence for the thermodynamic feasibility of 3d-TM@C3N3. Their findings indicate that all the calculated defect formation energy values are below zero, thus affirming the thermodynamic plausibility of 3d-TM@C3N3. Zhang et al. [12], employing the damping of van der Waals correction (DFT-D2) [13] calculations, have corroborated these conclusions. However, it is important to note that 3d-TM@C3N3 can exist in different charge states. This can be attributed to the replacement of C or N atoms by different 3d-TM or their embedding in an interstitial site, leading to a charge imbalance state. This necessitates further calculations that take into account the charge state of the 3d-TM@C3N3. Moreover, it is crucial to recognize that the previous neutral defect formation energy calculation is independent of the position of the Fermi level [14]. In reality, the defect formation energies are a function of the Fermi level, a fact that can provide valuable insights to experimentalists aiming to produce a material with specific defect-related properties. Therefore, it is imperative to accurately determine the stability region of 3d-TM@C3N3 in the chemical potential space and further investigate the role of defect charge states in 3d-TM@C3N3 OER/ORR bifunctional catalysts. This will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the material's properties and potential applications. In this paper, the effect of defect charge states on the catalytic activity of bifunctional OER/ORR in 3d-TM@C3N3 (3d-TM = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and Cu) is investigated comprehensively by using the density functional theory (DFT) and machine learning (ML) method. It has been found that the Ni occupation N in 0 charge state ( Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 ), Ni occupation N in +1 charge state ( Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 ) and Ni interstitial sites in the +1 charge state ( Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 ) are displayed lower OER and ORR overpotential (η) and lower formation energy over a wide range of Fermi levels. This shows that Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 have outstanding application potential as a bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalyst. According to the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, we unearth that they are thermodynamically stable. Besides, the analysis of their electronic structures indicates that considering the charge states of these systems can decrease their band gaps, which leads to facilitating electron transfer and tuning their adsorption configuration and interaction strength of the oxygenated intermediates (*OH, *O, *OOH), thus optimizing their bifunctional OER/ORR activity. By further elucidating the origin of element-specific activity through ML predictions, we identify the 3d-states of the 3d band center (εd ) and the number of 3d electrons (Ne ) as the most effective descriptors for overpotentials of OER and ORR. Our findings have the potential to provide theoretical directions for the development of highly efficient bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts and open the pristine way for the application of the charged-defect approach in the study of semiconductor electrocatalysts. 2 Computational details In this study, we employ spin-polarized DFT for all first-principles calculations, utilizing the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [15,16]. The ion-electron interaction is depicted through the projector augmented wave (PAW) [17] method, with a cutoff energy set at 500eV. The exchange-correlation interaction is treated within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional. We set the energy convergence threshold at 10−4eV and the atomic force at 0.03eV/Å to ensure complete relaxation of all atomic positions. For the execution of free energy correction applied to all intermediate species, we employ the VASPKIT code[18]. The interaction strength between catalysts and oxygenated intermediates is investigated using the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) [19] approach, facilitated by the LOBSTER software. Visualization of figures is achieved using VESTA [20]. The uniformly scaled supercell size approach is used to reduce false Coulomb interactions in which the lateral lengths are equal (Lx = Ly = Lz, see Fig. S1) [21,22]. The detailed formulas for the formation energy and chemical potentials of defects calculations are provided in Note S1. The relevant data are listed in Tables S1-S3. Detailed formulas for bifunctional OER/ORR Gibbs free energy in an acidic medium are provided in Notes S2. In addition to these computational methods, we utilize ML algorithms within the Python3 environment, specifically leveraging the Scikit-learn package [23]. We select four distinct ML algorithms for this purpose: gradient boosted regression (GBR) [24,25], random forest regression (RFR) [26], support vector regression (SVR) [27], and k-neighbor regression (KNR) [27]. Further details regarding these four algorithms can be found in Note S3. To evaluate the precision of the models, we use both the coefficient of determination (R2) values and the root-mean-square error (RMSE). 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Formation energy This study introduces impurity 3d-TM atoms (3d-TM = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Sc) into the 3×3 g-C3N3 supercell, which has 54 C atoms and 54 N atoms (C54N54). We consider three distinct modes: 3d-TMC@C53N54 (TM doping on C site), 3d-TMN@C54N53 (TM doping on N site), and 3d-TMint@C54N54 (TM interstitial site occupation). Taking Ni as an example, the optimized structures of NiN@C54N53, NiC@C53N54, and Niint@C54N54 are depicted in Fig. S2. To ascertain the most favorable doping sites for TMC and TMN, we construct six potential doping sites (Fig. S1(d)) for total energy calculation. The equivalent nitrogen positions (N1, N3, and N5) and carbon positions (C2, C4, and C6) are identified, because EN1= EN3 = EN5 and EC2= EC4 = EC6, as shown in Fig. S3. Notably, the EN1 (−910.72eV) is found to be lower than EC2 (−907.54eV), suggesting a higher likelihood of 3d-TM atoms occupying the N position post-TM doping into g-C3N3. Further evidence supporting this conclusion is provided in Fig. S4, where the formation energies of TMN@C54N53 systems are consistently lower than those of TMC@C53N54 under both C-rich and N-rich conditions. This indicates a greater ease for TM to occupy the N position than the C position in the g-C3N3. Consequently, we select the N1 atom as the occupied site for 3d-TM atoms in subsequent investigations. For the 3d-TM interstitial site occupation, we consider TM atoms embedded in the central cavity, a configuration known to stabilize TM atoms [28,29], as exemplified by Niint@C54N54 in Fig. S5. The band gap of monolayer g-C3N3, calculated at the PBE level, is found to be 1.54eV (Fig. S6(a)), aligning well with previous reports [30,31]. However, when calculated using the Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE) [32] functional, the band gap of single-layer g-C3N3 is 2.89eV (Fig. S6(b)), which is closer to the experimental value [33](2.89eV). Despite the accuracy of HSE calculations, they are computationally demanding. Fortunately, prior studies [34–37] have shown that the formation energy as a function of the Fermi level for PBE is nearly identical to that calculated by the HSE method. Therefore, in this study, we based all defect formation energy calculations on PBE-level computations. In both N-rich and C-rich conditions, we compute the formation energies of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 in various charge states (±2, ±1, and 0) as a function of the Fermi level to examine the convergence of the charge state. As depicted in Fig. S7-S8, for both 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems, the formation energy of the −2 charge state is consistently higher than that of the −1 and 0 charge states when the charge state is negative. Similarly, the formation energy of the +2 charge state surpasses that of the +1 and 0 charge states when the charge state is positive. These findings suggest that the calculated charge states converge, as the unreasonable charge states exhibit relatively higher formation energies. For enhanced clarity, we have not only plotted the complete line for each charge state of each defect (Figs. S7–S8) but also highlighted the section where a particular charge state has lower formation energy than all other charge states, as summarized in Fig. 1 . The slope changes in these lines signify a shift in the defect's charge state. As demonstrated in Fig. 1, the results indicate that most 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems are stable with 0 and +1 charge states. Additionally, the +2 charge state of Tiint@C54N54 and Mnint@C54N54 systems also exhibit stability. Consequently, as shown in Fig. 1(e), 30 types of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems in different charge states are stable, which are included in subsequent calculations focusing on bifunctional OER/ORR catalytic activity. For 3d-TMN@C54N53, as illustrated in Fig. 1(a)(b), under N-rich and C-rich conditions, the defects with the lowest formation energy are MnN@C54N53 when EF<0.47eV, and NiN@C54N53 when EF>0.47eV. However, ScN@C54N53 exhibits the highest formation energy for all Fermi level values under these conditions, indicating the difficulty of doping Sc on the N site in g-C3N3. For 3d-TMint@C54N54 under N-rich and C-rich conditions (Fig. 1(c and d)), Mnint@C54N54 consistently presents the lowest formation energy defect for all Fermi level values, suggesting a greater ease of formation. 3.2 OER/ORR activities In addition to analyzing the geometric structures, formation energies, and charge states of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54, we investigate their OER, ORR, and bifunctional OER/ORR catalytic activity. The OER and ORR are recognized as two reverse processes of O2 +2H2 ⇌ 2H2O, operating via a four-electron associative mechanism [38,39], as detailed in Fig. S9. Previous studies have established that the adsorption Gibbs free energies changes of the oxygenated intermediates (ΔG*OH, ΔG*O, and ΔG*OOH) on catalysts are critical determinants of their intrinsic catalytic activity toward the OER/ORR [40–42]. Consequently, we calculate the Gibbs free energy change for each elementary reaction step of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 to systematically explore the bifunctional OER/ORR catalytic mechanism. Our findings reveal that all the oxygenated intermediates preferentially adsorb at TM sites with TM-O bindings in the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 (Table S4), corroborating previous theoretical studies [43,44]. We compute the ΔG*OH, ΔG*O, and ΔG*OOH as outlined in Eq. S14 (Table S5). The free energy diagrams of the OER/ORR process for the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 under the potentials of U=0 and U=1.23V are then plotted (Figs. S10 and S11). Given their inverse nature, the OER proceeds from left to right, while the ORR operates in the opposite direction(from right to left). In practical terms, the free energy of two adjacent oxygenated intermediates in the OER or ORR is rarely equal, leading to a reaction rate that is invariably limited by a specific elementary reaction, known as the potential-determining step (PDS) [45,46]. In the OER process, the PDS is the step with the maximum potential increment, whereas in the ORR process, it is the step with the minimum potential drop. The catalyst activity, which is closely tied to the reaction rate, is gauged by the overpotential (ηORR/ηOER), defined as the difference between the potential change at the PDS and the equilibrium potential of 1.23V. We summarize the ηORR and ηOER for 30 variants of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems at different charge states in Fig. 2 (a and b). At the same time, we use ΔE=ηOER + ηORR as a metric to evaluate the bifunctional catalytic performance of OER and ORR (Fig. 2c), which is consistent with previous research [46,47]. A smaller ΔE value indicates superior bifunctional catalytic activity. As depicted in Fig. 2(b and c), the lowest η values at different charge states are observed in Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 , with ηOER/ηORR of 0.54/0.46V, 0.47/0.26V, and 0.36/0.47V, respectively. Given their superior ΔE values (1.00V/0.73V/0.83V), lower than the 1.01V of the standard material Ru/C [48]. Notably, the bifunctional catalytic activity of Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 outperform some reported catalysts, as listed in Table S6. This analysis confirms that Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 are promising candidates for effective bifunctional OER/ORR catalysts. As depicted in Fig. S12(a, c, e), the PDS of OER for the Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 systems is identified as *OH →*O (the second proton-coupled electron transfer step, ΔG2). Regarding ORR, Fig. S12(b, d, f) demonstrates that the formation of H2O (the first proton-coupled electron transfer step, ΔG1) is the PDS for the Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 systems. Furthermore, Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and Mn int × @ C 54 N 54 demonstrate high OER performance with overpotentials of 0.35 and 0.47V, respectively, comparable to, and even surpassing, the state-of-the-art RuO2 (0.42V) [49]. This suggests their significant potential as effective OER catalysts. Surprisingly, Cu int • @ C 54 N 54 exhibits the excellent ORR catalytic performance with the ηORR of 0.45V, which is identical with conventional noble metal Pt(1 1 1) (0.45V) [50]. This finding suggests that Cu int • @ C 54 N 54 could be considered as a promising ORR catalyst. Considering the strong correlation effect of transition metals, we further refine the overpotential for Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 using the GGA+U approach [51], the details are listed in Note S4. 3.3 OER/ORR activity origin 3.3.1 Scaling relations of intermediates adsorption and 2D volcano plots Given that the OER/ORR is a multistep process involving the oxygenated intermediates, it is advantageous to identify an activity descriptor, ideally based on a single intermediate. This approach simplifies the parametric space for catalytic activity by reducing the number of degrees of freedom, thereby enabling the prediction of a general trend. With this objective in mind, we examine the scaling relations of ΔG*O, ΔG*OOH, and ΔG*OH, which are illustrated in Fig. 3 (a and b). These relations are based on the Gibbs free energies of adsorbed oxygenated intermediates, as detailed in Table S5. The relationships we derived can be expressed as follows: (11a) ΔG*OOH = 0.90G*OH + 3.04 (R2 = 0.97) (11b) ΔG* O=1.78G*OH + 1.02 (R2 = 0.96). It is evident that ΔG*O, ΔG*OOH and ΔG*OH exhibit a strong linear relationship, as indicated by the high R2 values. This correlation is likely due to the similar bond order nature of TM-OOH, TM-O, and TM-OH. Consequently, ΔG*OH, ΔG*O, and ΔG*OOH can serve as suitable descriptors to explain the catalytic activities of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 materials. Furthermore, an effective catalyst should exhibit moderate ΔGi (i=1, 2, 3, 4) values to ensure that the adsorption of oxygenated intermediates is neither excessively strong nor weak. The ideal electrocatalyst would possess ΔG*OH, ΔG*O, and ΔG*OOH values of approximately 1.23eV, 2.46eV, and 3.69eV, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 3(a and b), the ΔG*OH and ΔG*OOH values of Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 , Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 are significantly closer to those of the ideal electrocatalyst compared to other systems. This proximity results in high OER/ORR activity in these models. To further elucidate the catalytic activity of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems, as well as the distribution of the PDS, we employ two descriptors: ΔG* O−ΔG*OH and ΔG*OH. These descriptors represent the catalytic activity of the OER and ORR, respectively. Specifically, we substitute ΔG*OOH with Eq. (11a) in Eq. S14 to derive Eq. 12a, which we then use to evaluate the catalytic activity of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems using ΔG* O−ΔG*OH and ΔG*OH. (12a) ΔG1= ΔG*OH (12b) ΔG2=ΔG* O−ΔG*OH (12c) ΔG3= − 0.10ΔG*OH − (ΔG* O −ΔG*OH) +3.04 (12d) ΔG4= −0.90ΔG*OH + 1.88 In essence, this approach allows us to calculate the adsorption energy of each species by obtaining the ΔG*O and ΔG*OH values. Under these conditions, the contour map accurately depicts the catalytic activity of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. We solve Eq. 12a collectively to delineate the boundaries that partition the entire region into four. As illustrated in Fig. 3(c and d), each region represents the free energy changes for the fundamental steps of the OER/ORR. Regarding the PDS of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems during the catalytic process, the corresponding elementary reaction is considered when the catalyst falls within a certain region. In Fig. 3c, the PDS of the OER can be primarily attributed to the *OOH → * + O2, *OH → *O, and * O→ *OOH reactions. This suggests that O2, *O, and *OOH are challenging to form but may be simpler to shape in the OER process. The detailed PDSOER is provided in Table S7. Moreover, the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems can easily split H2O in the OER, while the reverse process in the ORR is more difficult. In the context of the ORR, as shown in Fig. 3d, the PDS of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems primarily involves step 4 (*OH → * + H2O). This implies that the formation of H2O is the most significant hurdle in the ORR process (Table S7), which aligns with our previous conclusion. Therefore, our computations are accurate. All the overpotentials of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54, shown in Fig. 3(c and d) and Table S7, are displayed in various colors between 0.23 and 4.06V. We denote excellent and ineffective catalytic performance using red and blue sections, respectively. The closer the sample points are to the center, the better the catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 3c, Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 is the most promising candidate for the OER process among all the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems, exhibiting an outstanding OER overpotential of 0.35V. Meanwhile, the Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 system, with an ηORR of 0.26V and a near-central location in Fig. 3d, is the best candidate for the ORR process. These findings are consistent with our previous conclusions, further validating the accuracy of our research. 3.3.2 Electronic structure properties To elucidate the superior electrochemical catalytic capabilities of Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 , we have conducted a detailed analysis of the adsorption configuration of oxygen intermediates and performed a Bader charge analysis, as depicted in Fig. S14. The Bader charge amounts of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems are listed in Table S8. It is evident that the angle of the oxygen intermediates adsorbed on the Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 substrates undergo a significant alteration compared to the neutral system. Specifically, the Ni-O-O angle experiences a substantial shift from 99.04° to 105.72° when the charge state of the N i N @ C 54 N 53 the system is modified, as illustrated in Fig. S14(a and b). Furthermore, we have employed Bader charge analysis to discern the interaction between Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 , Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 , Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 , and the oxygen intermediate, which is a determinant of its adsorption strength. As shown in Fig. S14, it is clear that all oxygenated intermediates are chemically adsorbed onto the TM atom via the Ni-O bond, and a significant charge transfer from the Ni atom to the O atom occurs. The total amount of charge transfer for *O, *OH, and *OOH (Qtotal) follows the order: Qtotal (*O) > Qtotal (*OH) > Qtotal (*OOH). This suggests that the greater the number of atoms involved in adsorption, the fewer electrons are transferred. Importantly, when considering the charge states in N i N @ C 54 N 53 and N i int @ C 54 N 53 systems, the Qtotal decreases, but the charge transfer of Ni atoms (Ni-Qe) is larger than that in the neutral systems. Therefore, by shifting the Fermi level towards the valence band (Fig. 1), we can adjust the Qtotal and the charge transfer of TM atoms (Qe ) of the catalysts in the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems to achieve optimal bifunctional OER/ORR activity. Consequently, in addition to the adsorption configuration of oxygen intermediates, the Qtotal and Qe will be affected when the charge states are considered in 3d-TM@C54N53 and 3d-TM@C54N54 systems. To further understand the nature of the adsorption behavior of oxygenated intermediates and display the bonding interaction relationship between TM and oxygenated intermediates more intuitively, we introduce the projected COHP(pCOHP) and the integrated value of COHP (ICOHP) to analyze the bonding and antibonding states after the *OH intermediate is adsorbed on metal pairs as shown in Figs. S15 and S16. Herein, the pCOHP is plotted to draw the bonding contributions to the right and the antibonding contributions to the left. The more negative ICOHP values are, the stronger the bonding interaction of TM−OH is, based on previous research [34,52]. Thus, the bond interactions between *OH intermediate and 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems become weaker after increasing d electrons. Meanwhile, the charged systems display reduced ICOHPs compared to their neutral counterparts, meaning that the accession of charge states can enhance the mutual relationship between the TM atoms and *OH intermediate. This result implies that the charge state potentially boosts electron occupancy in the TM-O bond's bonding states, thereby reinforcing the TM-O bond. To confirm this deduction, the ΔG*OH versus ICOHP relationship is delineated in Fig. S17. There's a clear linear correlation between the two variables with a fit of R2 = 0.65. A higher ICOHP is indicative of more robust species adsorption. This study provides a quantitative perspective on the influence of various 3d-TM centers and charge states in dictating the balance of bonding and antibonding states, ultimately defining the bonding strengths with *OH. The electrical conductivity of a system, which significantly influences the efficiency of electron transfer, is a critical factor in the electrocatalytic reaction process alongside the COHP. Therefore, we have investigated the total density of states (TDOS) and projected density of states (PDOS) of Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 , Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 due to their lower ηOER/ηORR and ΔE. To rectify the underestimation of the band gap by the PBE method, we employ the screened hybrid functional of HSE to provide a more accurate description of the electronic structure. We test the band gap of pristine g-C3N3 by adjusting the Hartree-Fock mixing parameter (α) from 0.12 to 0.3. Our findings reveal that at α = 0.242, the calculated band gap of g-C3N3 is 2.89eV, aligning with previous reports [53]. The results of the TDOS and PDOS of Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 , Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 are shown in Fig. 4 (a–d). For comparison, their TDOS and PDOS use the PBE functional are depicted in Fig. S18. Furthermore, we examine the PDOS of 3d TM for 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems at various charge states (Figs. S19 and S20). Notably, the εd is often considered as the activity descriptor. Based on our PDOS results, we calculate their εd values, which are provided in Table S9. It is evident that the ε d for 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems vary, suggesting that the adsorption capacity of these systems is highly dependent on the charge states and 3d-TM species. Moreover, we investigate the total magnetic properties of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems (μB0 ), and after oxygenated intermediates absorbing 3d-TM@C54N53, 3d-TM@C54N54 systems (μB-OH, μB-O, μB-OOH ). The results, summarized in Table S10, indicate that the magnetic nature primarily stems from the 3d state of TM due to the asymmetric spin-up and spin-down channels. The band gaps of the neutral systems, Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 (2.46eV, Fig. 4a) and Ni int × @ C 54 N 53 (2.19eV, Fig. 4b), are observed to be higher than those of the charged systems, Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 (2.33eV, Fig. 4c) and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 (1.66eV, Fig. 4d). This observation suggests that the charge state of these systems inversely affects their band gap, thereby facilitating electron transfer. The underlying mechanism can be attributed to the ease with which electrons in the valence band are excited to cross the extremely narrow band gap to the conduction band, an enhanced process at high temperatures, thereby increasing the conductivity of a semiconductor [54]. Consequently, the electrical conductivity of these catalysts could be augmented, improving their electrocatalytic efficiency. This finding explains the observed higher bifunctional ORR/OER catalytic activity of the charged systems, Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 (ΔE = 0.73V) and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 (ΔE = 0.83V), compared to the neutral systems, Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 (ΔE = 1.00V) and Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 (ΔE = 1.19V), as depicted in Fig. 2c. The thermal stability of the Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 , Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 systems is assessed using AIMD simulations. A canonical (NVT) ensemble is employed to maintain a constant temperature of 300K, with temperature regulation facilitated by the Nosé–Hoover thermostat [55,56]. As illustrated in Fig. 4(e–h), the variations in temperature and energy over an 8ps period and the initial and final structures of the AIMD simulations for the systems mentioned above at 300K are demonstrated. It is evident from the simulations that the overall frameworks of these systems undergo only minor changes throughout the entire dynamics calculations process. None of the structures exhibit significant structural reconstruction, and they can revert to their initial structures following structural relaxation. This suggests that these systems exhibit robust thermal stability. 3.4 Algorithm selection and ml model performance After we explore the relationship between the electronic structure, adsorption energy, and catalytic activity of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems, it becomes evident that a deeper understanding of the intrinsic factors influencing catalytic activity is necessary. Prior research has shown that integrating ML and DFT can effectively illuminate the inherent relationship between descriptors and indicators in catalytic reactions [17,18,57,58]. Consequently, we employ the ML approach to establish a correlation between the bifunctional OER/ORR activity and the fundamental physical and chemical properties of the 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. We select the fourteen properties of 3d-TM atoms, 3d-TMN@C54N53, and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems as input data for ML [59], which are divided into two groups, shown in Fig. 5 (a). This selection encompasses five values of atomic size and structural features: electronegativity (Nm ), electron affinity (χm , eV), first ionization energy (Im , eV), the radius of the TM atom (rd , pm), and Ne . In addition to these descriptors representing the fundamental atomic characteristics of isolated 3d-TM atoms, we also choose descriptors related to chemical properties determined via DFT calculations. These include the εd , the total magnetic moment (in μB) before (μB0 ), and after (μB-OH, μB-O, μB-OOH ) oxygenated intermediates absorbing 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems (Table S10), the bond length of TM and coordination atoms (dTM-OH, dTM-O and dTM-OOH , Å), and Qe (Table S11). Our dataset is randomly divided into a training set and a test set at a ratio of 9:1. We evaluate ML algorithms, including GBR, RFR, SVR, and KNR (Note S2). Each algorithm underwent round-robin testing to identify the set with the most accurate RMSE and R2 values, which are used to assess the prediction accuracy of the algorithm. The RMSE represents the model's average error, while the R2 value indicates the model's accuracy score. Therefore, an optimal ML model would exhibit a smaller RMSE and larger R2 values. The RMSE and R2 values for different algorithms of OER and ORR are presented in Fig. 5(b and c), respectively. Notably, for GBR and RFR, we conduct 1000 repetitions of training using consistent training parameters to minimize deviations in the ML model. The R2 values and RMSE used in Fig. 5(b and c) represent the average value from these repetitions. Evidently, the GBR models outperform the other three ML models in both ORR and OER predictions, boasting the lowest RMSE (0.001V for both ORR and OER) and the highest R2 score (0.99 for both ORR and OER) in training. The RFR and KNR models exhibit moderate performance in training due to their relatively higher RMSE (ranging from 0.06 to 0.90V) and lower R2 score (ranging from 0.20 to 0.99). In stark contrast, the SVR model performs poorly, with the highest RMSE (0.24V for ORR and 0.20V for OER) and the lowest R2 score (0.87 for ORR and 0.89 for OER) for both reactions. We have graphically represented the DFT-calculated OER and ORR overpotential values versus predicted values, indicating R2 and RMSE (Fig. S21). The GBR models consistently achieve the best test score in these four ML algorithms, as depicted in Fig. S21. Notably, in 1000 repetitions of training, the GBR model's worst performance scores for ORR are 0.88 and 0.08eV for R2 and RMSE (with average values of R2 ave = 0.99 and RMSEave = 0.001eV), respectively, as shown in Fig. 5d. For OER, the average values are R2 ave =0.99 and RMSEave = 0.001eV (Fig. 5e). These results demonstrate that the GBR-predicted overpotentials align closely with the DFT-calculated values, exhibiting a clear linear relationship for both the training and test sets. This indicates that the effectively trained GBR models can accurately predict catalytic activities. Consequently, we chose the GBR models for further activity prediction and mechanism analysis for ORR and OER. Next, we investigate the feature importance (the contribution of each feature to OER and ORR activities) of the GBR models, as depicted in Fig. 5(f and g). For OER, as shown in Fig. 5f, the descriptors εd (21.16%), rd (19.30%), Im (17.89%), and Ne (13.70%) collectively exhibit a significant correlation with ηOER, each contributing more than 10%. Remarkably, these descriptors cumulatively account for 72.05% of the feature weight, thereby playing a crucial role in influencing ηOER efficacy. The remaining eigenvalues have a less pronounced impact on the performance metric. For ηORR, as illustrated in Fig. 5g, Ne (38.36%), rd (33.17%), and μB-OOH (12.06%) emerge as the dominant descriptors, each contributing significantly (greater than 10%) to the ηORR performance. The combined feature weight for these three eigenvalues totals 83.59%, highlighting their substantial correlation with overpotential and validating their role as crucial descriptors in the predictive modeling of ORR activity. In conclusion, this comprehensive analysis identifies the primary descriptors that significantly influence the electrocatalytic performance metrics of OER and ORR. These insights provide a foundation for targeted material optimization and improved predictive modeling. Our research has identified that the Ne and εd are the primary factors influencing the OER and ORR, respectively. Notably, εd is associated with the chemical properties determined through DFT calculations. These properties can be modulated by controlling the doped 3d TM species, charge states, and Fermi level. Consequently, we propose a linear correlation between Ne, εd , and the Gibbs free energy of adsorption for ΔG*OH, ΔG*O, ΔG*OOH. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , the ΔG*OH, ΔG*O, ΔG*OOH can be linearly correlated with Ne (R2=0.84–0.88) and εd (R2=0.64–0.78). This correlation strongly supports the use of Ne and εd as effective descriptors for determining the catalytic activity of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. This conclusion is further supported by corroborative evidence in reference [60], which identifies the charge-transfer energy as a potent descriptor in designing graphitic carbon-nitride catalysts for OER and ORR. This evidence suggests that our ML results are reliable. 5 Conclusions In summary, we have utilized DFT calculations and ML predictions to investigate the bifunctional OER/ORR catalytic activity of 3d-TMN@C54N53 and 3d-TMint@C54N54 systems. We have comprehensively investigated the formation energies, ΔG, and η of 3d-TMs doped monolayer g-C3N3 in both neutral and charged states. Our findings indicate that Ni N × @ C 54 N 53 , Ni int • @ C 54 N 54 , and Ni N • @ C 54 N 53 exhibit low overpotentials for OER and ORR. These results, combined with a decrease in formation energy across a broad range of Fermi levels, suggest that these systems have significant potential as OER/ORR catalysts. Besides, Ni int × @ C 54 N 54 and Mn int • • @ C 54 N 54 are competent candidates as OER electrocatalysts with low overpotentials of 0.35V, 0.47V, respectively, and Cu int • @ C 54 N 54 could be considered as a promising ORR catalyst as will. Furthermore, our research indicates that the bifunctional OER/ORR activity of the defective g-C3N3 is influenced not only by the doped 3d TM species, as previously assumed, but also by the formation energies, charge state, and Fermi level's position of the defects. According to the electronic structure analysis, the band gaps of these systems are decreased when they are charged, which can facilitate electron transfer and tune their adsorption configuration and interaction strength of the oxygenated intermediates, thus optimal their bifunctional OER/ORR activity. Our results suggest that charged states can enhance the 3d TM doped g-C3N3 efficiency as effective bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts. Moreover, by further elucidating the origin of element-specific activity through ML predictions, we identify εd and the Ne as the most effective descriptors for overpotentials of OER and ORR, respectively. Therefore, our research offers new insights for designing efficient electrocatalysts for applications such as metal-air batteries, water splitting, and regenerative fuel cells. coredata.dc:description: Pursuing efficient bifunctional oxygen reduction reaction/ oxygen evolution reaction (OER/ORR) electrocatalysts is crucial for realizing sustainable and renewable clean energy, yet it remains a formidable challenge. In this study, we employ density functional theory and machine learning (ML) predictions to systematically investigate the bifunctional OER/ORR activity of 3d transition metal (TM) atom-doped g-C3N3. Our findings reveal that N-rich and C-poor growth conditions can facilitate 3d TM doping into g-C3N3. The Ni occupation N in 0 (Ni× N@C54N53, including 54 C and 53 N atoms), Ni occupation N in +1 (Ni• N@C54N53) and Ni interstitial sites in +1 charge state (Ni• int@C54N54, including 54 C and 54 N atoms) meet the requirements of bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts, which because they (1) have lower formation energies, and (2) lower overpotentials (smaller than 0.47V), (3) can maintain stability under 300K and (4) their band gaps are decreased, which leads to facilitating electron transfer. ML predictions identify the 3d band center (εd ) and the number of 3d electrons (Ne ) as the most effective descriptors for overpotentials of OER and ORR, respectively. This work can pave the way for understanding the origin of bifunctional OER/ORR activity of 3d-TM doped g-C3N3 and benefit the rational design of novel electrocatalysts for other catalytic reactions by considering the charge states.
coredata.dc:title: Increasing the bifunctional OER/ORR activity of 3d transition metals doped g-C3N3 by controlling the charge states
